content.text:
Slips, Trips and Falls in the workplace are an ever present hazard and can result in far more serious consequences than minor abrasions or bruising. A slip or fall can cause injury to the arms, legs, back, neck or head.

Neck and head injuries can cause damage to the spinal cord and nervous system. Many workers have suffered permanent disabling injuries or death as a result of a fall.
The objective of this lesson is that workers can identify slip, trip and fall hazards and demonstrate a general understanding of  minimising and eliminating the risks.

slides.templateDescription: Display a video hosted on YouTube

data.prompt: Drag to set the correct value

answer.text: Slips, Trips and Falls accounted for just over **30%** of all accidents in 2015 - the most significant single contributor to workplace injuries.

data.title: What percentage of workplace injuries were caused by Slips, Trips and Falls in 2015, compared to other accident types?

question.category: What percentage of workplace injuries were caused by Slips, Trips and Falls in 2015, compared to other accident types?
What percentage of workplace injuries were caused by Slips, Trips and Falls in 2015, compared to other accident types?

data.prompt: Put the items in the correct order

answer.text:
Although there are several different factors, a **wet floor surface** is the most common contributor to Slips, Trips and Falls. 

Ensure you clean up any spills or debris immediately.

list: Floor surface – wet, slippery or containing obstacles.
data.title: Rank the factors contributing to Slips, Trips and Falls order of their occurrence rate.

question.content: Rank the factors contributing to Slips, Trips and Falls order of their occurrence rate.

answers.content: Floor surface – wet, slippery or containing obstacles. | Obstructed vision | Unsuitable footwear | Unstable walkways

data.prompt: Tap the best reply to the message

answer.text:
Make sure your footwear complies with company standards, and point out the risks to anyone you see in unsuitable footwear. 

Shoes should be cleated, soft rubber soles and have heels with ankle support

incorrect: You're right, any type of footwear will be fine. Companies would be sued if they made footwear with poor grip.
answers.correct: The rules about footwear aren't for fun; they are there to protect your safety. Your footwear needs to meet company standards.

message.content: It doesn't matter what footwear I use as long as I don't get caught.

question.content: It doesn't matter what footwear I use as long as I don't get caught.

answers.content: The rules about footwear aren't for fun; they are there to protect your safety. Your footwear needs to meet company standards.
You're right, any type of footwear will be fine. Companies would be sued if they made footwear with poor grip.

slides.templateDescription: Display a list of bullet points

list.content:
- Wear shoes with cleated, soft rubber soles and heels with ankle support.
- Walking areas must be clear of obstacles.
- Slip resistant mats should be applied to risk areas.
- Spills should be cleaned up immediately.
list.title: Floor surface – wet, slippery or containing obstacles.

list.content:
- There should be sufficient lighting in every workplace.
- Look carefully when walking.
- Don't carry oversized objects that limit vision.
list.title: Obstructed vision

list.content:
- Watch out for:
 - Unstable floorboards
 - Uneven tiles
 - Slick rugs and mats
list.title: Unstable walkways.

data.title: Review the causes of Slips, Trips and Falls and their solutions
Pair the Trip and Slip risks with their solutions.

pairs.left: Floor surface – wet, slippery or containing obstacles.
pairs.right: Keeping walking areas clear of obstacles, and adding slip resistant mats to high risk areas
Looking carefully where you are going, and not carrying oversized objects that limit vision
Taking care to watch out for unstable and unsafe walkways

answer.text: It's easy to avoid Slips, Trips and Falls as long as you follow these simple steps.
